thread.title: Mother and Daughter Commit Suicide Together by Stepping in Front of Commuter Train
thread.title_full: Mother and Daughter Commit Suicide Together by Stepping in Front of Commuter Train

author: Cosmopolitan.com
title: Mother and Daughter Commit Suicide Together by Stepping in Front of Commuter Train
text:
A mother and daughter committed suicide together at a London train station, a coroner ruled Thursday. ​The Express reports Celise McLean and her 17-year-old daughter Leia ​linked arms and walked in front of an oncoming train in June. A subsequent investigation into their deaths revealed letters found at their home that served as good-bye notes to people who knew them.
Adult and Child hit by train and killed at Ealing Broadway very sad and very tragic. Police all over the place. pic.twitter.com/56RJM0K7lm
— BrownEyes (@GadgetGirl_40) June 23, 2015
 On the evening of June 23, horrified commuters at the Ealing Broadway station witnessed McLean and her daughter die after being struck by a rush-hour train. Earlier, the two had been seen at a nearby KFC, eating what would be their last meal. During the coroner's inquest, witnesses described ​Celise McLean ​ as "agitated" and exhibiting strange behavior when she arrived at the train station. ​ ​
More From Cosmopolitan Celise McLean was overheard by a witness saying, " ​ I have to get to Heathrow, I have to stop them." The mother and daughter had also asked how to get a train to the airport. A witness told the inquest she saw the mother put her bag down moments before walking across the platform with her daughter.
​"They linked arms before running towards the platform edge," the witness said.
The two were later identified from a bank card in the woman's bag. Police said Celise McLean also had a son, Devon. " ​ When he came home from school at about 5 p.m on the back of a chair were taped various letters addressed to different people." ​ British Transport Police Detective Sergeant Andrew Nattrass said. "From reading these letters they effectively amount to farewell letters."
A coroner ruled both deaths a suicide. Family members present at the inquest declined to speak with media.
